content.question:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

A robotics company is developing a robotic claw that can grab paper clips. The company is investigating the number of clips that can be grabbed by the claw at one time based on the size of the claw. The following scatterplot shows the number of clips grabbed by <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> claws, with claw size measured as the span of the claw in centimeters (<math alttext="c m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>).

Two models have been proposed to predict the number of clips from claw size. Model <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math> is given as the following.

<math alttext="predicted number of clips equals, 3.179 plus 1.032 times claw size" overflow="scroll"><mtext>predicted number of clips</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>3.179</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>1.032</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>claw size</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>

(a) Interpret the slope of Model <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math> in context.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

A robotics company is developing a robotic claw that can grab paper clips. The company is investigating the number of clips that can be grabbed by the claw at one time based on the size of the claw. The following scatterplot shows the number of clips grabbed by <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> claws, with claw size measured as the span of the claw in centimeters (<math alttext="c m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>).

Two models have been proposed to predict the number of clips from claw size. Model <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math> is given as the following.

<math alttext="predicted number of clips equals, 3.179 plus 1.032 times claw size" overflow="scroll"><mtext>predicted number of clips</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>3.179</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>1.032</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>claw size</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>

(a) Interpret the slope of Model <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math> in context.
(b) Explain why the intercept of Model <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math> is not meaningful in context.

(c) Model <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mtext>II</mtext></math> has an intercept of <math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and is given as the following.

<math alttext="predicted number of clips equals 1.190 times claw size" overflow="scroll"><mtext>predicted number of clips</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>1.190</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>claw size</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>

(i) Consider the claw of size <math alttext="18 centimeters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that grabbed <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> clips. Calculate the residual for this observation using both models. Show your work.

Model <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"> <mtext>I</mtext> </math> residual:

Model <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mtext>II</mtext></math> residual:

(ii) Which of the two models provides a better prediction for a claw of size <math alttext="18 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that grabbed <math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> clips? Justify your answer.

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Construct numerical or graphical representations of distributions.
